text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC three takeaways from Barack
Obama's news conference today announcing
his economic team the first is that
Barack Obama is beginning a more active
phase of his transition to the
presidency you heard him immediately
after the election reiterate that we
only have one president at a time
indicated he was going to take his time
getting ready for the job as he put
together his team but now he's talking
about getting daily briefings on the
economic situation from the bush
administration and beginning a much more
aggressive phase of preparing for the
presidency the second thing is the team
is putting together is truly a team of
big brains big personalities it's
extraordinary that Larry Summers who was
the finalist for Treasury secretary who
did not get the job Tim Geithner from
the New York Federal Reserve Bank did is
going into the White House as head of
the National Economic Council what
Barack Obama is counting on is his
leadership at this time of crisis to be
stronger than the individual ego these
players get them all pulling together on
the same team to try to get the United
States economy out of this mess the
third thing to remember is that they're
thinking big in terms of stimulus Barack
Obama said today that he wants a
stimulus package large enough to jolt
this economy back to life he's not
putting a number on it his last proposal
in the campaign was a hundred and
seventy five billion dollars this is
going to be much larger than that some
on the hill are talking about stimulus
as high as seven hundred billion dollars
there's an acceptance by all parties
left and right that we're going to have
a much larger budget deficit and they're
accepting that budget deficit one of the
key questions for Barack Obama that he
did not answer today is whether he's
going to defer his attempt to raise
taxes on investors upper income
Americans some on his team are betting
that he is going to let those expire
rather than seek their early repeal
Barack Obama didn't commit on that but
everybody knows that we are looking at a
large package that he hopes to get
Congress started on in early January
when the new Congress takes office even
before he's sworn in so they can sign
that package into law very very quickly
after getting sworn in on january
twentieth I'm John Harwood chief
Washington correspondent for CNBC
